glance/api/v2/images.py.message:
I saw in the log that somehow passed target data is not formatted properly in oslo policy[1]. Not sure why.

"target=cannot format data, exception: You are not permitted to modify 'hw_rng_model' on this image."

Error is coming from here
- https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/cab28649c689067970a51a2f9b329bdd6a0f0501/oslo_policy/policy.py#L930

[1]https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/aa1a5cd62aaa4210b19a5877e77b87db/log/controller/logs/screen-g-api.txt#600

i see, thanks for updates. its working fine with master oslo policy with 740068.

Yeah it is debug log issue, not functionality.

This is due to a deepcopy in the debug paths of oslo.policy, and is really a bug in glance's ImmutableImage and ImmutableProperty implementation. There is an oslo.policy patch merged to stop deepcopying the objects which will help alleviate the issue, but it's just debug output and does not affect the functioning of the code at all.

After all those other conflict checks have happened at lines 112-133, what we're really interested in at this point is whether the image can be mutated in this context.  I think it would be more clear to write the condition like this:

    if not authorization.is_image_mutable(req.context, image):
        if import_method == 'copy-image':
            # if the policy allows us to do this, the context will be
            # escalated to allow mutation at the appropriate time
            self.policy.enforce(req.context, 'copy_image',
                                dict(policy.ImageTarget(image)))
        else:
            raise webob.exc.HTTPForbidden(
                explanation=_("Operation not permitted"))

(What I'm afraid of is that someone will add another check in lines 112-133 that will somehow inappropriately miss this mutability check if it's hidden in the else.)

I agree that the policy knob should actually work, so let's keep the code the way you have it.  I will settle for a blank line before line 134 to signal that this if/else block is a bit different from the others.

I think your code here would *not* allow the admin to use the policy knob to deny copying images to users when they already own it right? Meaning, if the operator wanted to say "even if you own the image, you can't copy it if the container_format is foobar", the policy check would be skipped in the case where they own the image (i.e. it is mutable). I think it's important for the policy check to be a first-class citizen in order to behave the way the operator would expect (i.e. that if I disable copy-image, it's disabled).

What if I changed the:

  else:
      if not authorization...

to:

  elif not authorization...

?

That would elevate it to the elif level at least, although I'll be honest and say I'm not quite sure I get the concern. Any other checks that abort the request added above this will be fine, assuming they're of the same type as those we have now, which are all state/workflow-related.
Okay, I'mma convert to elif because there's no reason not to and add a blank line plus a comment about the reasoning which should help set this off from the checks above.

README.rst.message: Rather merged to the main/release branch, right? There are already committed in the repo.

Actually in Gerrit it's called a "change".  I acknowledge some people call it a "review", but in fact, a "review" is something you leave on a "change".  I'm not pedantic enough to correct folks in conversation, but we should avoid saying the opposite in our docs.
There are also other types of tests, e.g, integration tests you mention below. Maybe a term, i.e., "automated tests" could be used here?
not only difficult to run consistently but more also the issue may be the time requirements on the run of the whole test set.
I know your goal is more conversational approach, which I really like, but from this sentence I feel a bit in a sales pitch :)
I would consider removing that, since you are negating it right away.
For brevity I think referencing Ansible is enough. You are mentioning 2 Ansible terms while ignoring others, e.g., tasks.

the thing is a big part of it is zuul-jobs with it's array of roles to help you out.  So I want someone who isn't familiar to sort of understand that roles are like functions you call where you don't really care how they do what they do, but that you get the result you want.
IMHO this goes too far into Ansible - scope?

Zuul is so closely tied to ansible now that I really feel to that to understand what zuul is getting at you need to understand why you'd use an orchestration tool like ansible.  I feel like it needs to be pretty deeply explained if you don't know what it even is.

I would maybe consider reformulating it:
- " ... transfer them to any desired destination."
- " ..."
..., an extended well established DRY principle
suggestion: "... to run the jobs on and eventual removal when job run finishes.
I would reformulate that 1st person speech
Suggestion: "... starts the jobs, using Ansible playbooks, agains these integration nodes"
If Zuul insulates them from you, how can you start to see them? :)
I would remove the example number, just keep: "..., other things ..."
"... it is save to merge them on top of each other!"
"... ensure others don't test test their commits on top-of-tree before previous changes are tested and merged"

You are using here a lot "commit" here. I believe that the issue is actually the testing and merging. It is IMHO a common use of other CIs too that you actually build-test your commit (PR, change) on top of HEAD/Trunk/... not on top of the origin of the branch.

Maybe it should be explained above more what is meant. Example of a typical CI workflow and than go from there with the examples in this text. 

The big innovation I understand you want to promote here is gating/speculative merging of changes on top of each other instead on top of HEAD, which gives the parallel testing in best case (without gate reset) a huge performance advantage.

A typical check pipeline tests the change against the HEAD (also common for other CIs), a typical gate pipeline lines up changes which are then build/tested on top of each other.

Just a suggestion.
a good point, i've reworked things to highlight more the speculative testing
This really depends on project's jobs and "flakyness" of each project's tests. I would suggest to reformulate or remove this.
People don't write tests to fail, however.  I mean you expect them to pass an flakyness is a bug, hopefully to be eliminated.  It think it's probably fair to say that tests are expected to pass
not sure if they are "ahead of you"
Maybe this part needs its own (sub-)section?
I would consider moving this paragraph down to "Project gating"

specs/victoria/support-modern-compressio.message:
What's the benefit of adding both lz4 and zstd algorithms?

IMO Cinder should be somewhat opinionated about which algorithms are best for cinder-backup, and only add more when there's a clear benefit.

As far as I checked, zstd is better in compression ratio with similar speed compared to lz4,
but lz4 is more generally available and supported.
(e.g. Rpm package for lz4 python binding is available in epel repo, but not for zstd.)

Of cource, zstd python binding is available from pypi.
So adding only zstd may be one choice. I want to hear more opinions from cinder members.

Brian also says we should pick one, and zstd is better in performance.
So I'll change this to only add zstd algorithm.

The concern is that the package for python-zstd is not provided for ubuntu and fedora. I'll try to explain if global-requirement team point on this.
(If they do not accept, I may switch to lz4.)

Looks good. But it would be better if you can put CPU consumption data here. 8 cores are all 100% busy in all the tests, right? I remember some may only use one core.

Another point is *famous* algorithms (like gzip) is well supported by hardware accelerator, can be offload easily. It would be good to mention this here (gzip may be not so bad as listed here if offloaded to hardware^-^)

I'm not saying I don't support this spec, just saying this spec can add more info if you like to do.

On my test, CPU usage for all algorithm was about 100%~110% where max usage is 800% (=8cores * 100%).
(i.e. Using only one core for compression.)

The zlib, bzip2 and zstd (version 1.4.4.0) python libraries does not support multi-thread compression.
But I checked again now and noticed zstd added support for multi-thread compression at version 1.4.4.1.

I will re-test with new zstd python library and add cpu consumption data here. (Maybe on monday.)
And I'll add notes about hardware accelarator then.
every line should be as many as 80 characters. Please also check other paragraphs.

* Propose python-zstd to the OpenStack global-requirements

You can use this as a sample of how to do it: https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/9b1ba719b75e1856ff6d897df847e401225babe2

Thanks for your advice. I proposed as follows.
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/740259/
(The sample config will be updated automatically when you change the 'choices' on the config option definition)

OK. I've already fixed the file in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/726765/2 .

And I'll fix the code to add only zstd (not with lz4).

One potential impact that should be called out here is that this could result in someone creating a backup in one cloud that has zstd enabled, then fail to restore that backup in a cloud that is running older code that does not have it.
Should probably at least add a note to https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/admin/blockstorage-volume-backups-export-import.html noting this new compression option.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: I guess the type is given as a string even if objects are imported due to the fact that objects dynamically exporting the sub packages. (I tried converting this to typename locally and it does not fail but I guess it is some local quirk for me still)

tl;dr: We should always surround any o.vo from 'nova.objects' in quotes, and we need to enclose imports inside a 'if ty.TYPE_CHECKING' conditional anytime we wish to avoid circular references.

This took me a while to grok but I think I've got it now. I think there are couple of intertwined issues here: circular dependencies, the "dynamic" loading behavior of the 'nova.objects' module, and differences in how Python the interpreter works and mypy. Consider the following snippet:

  def hello_world(foo: bar.Baz):
      pass

Because we have configured 'ignore_missing_imports' to 'True' in 'setup.cfg', mypy will complain if the 'bar' module isn't defined, but it won't check anything inside the 'bar' module unless this module is included in the list of scanned modules (currently loaded from 'mypy-files.txt')

By comparison, Python itself will actually try to load 'bar.Baz' just like it would if you were declaring a variable or subclass of this type. If 'bar' doesn't exist, you'll see the same undefined reference/import complaint that mypy issued. However, if 'Baz' doesn't exist in 'bar', it'll complain that the 'bar' module doesn't have the 'Baz' attribute.

That means something like this will fail:

  if ty.TYPE_CHECKING:
      import bar

  def hello_world(foo: bar.Baz):
      pass

This fails as everything inside the TYPE_CHECKING conditional only executes in the mypy context, so it's effectively 'if False' during runtime. However, you sometimes need to use the 'TYPE_CHECKING' conditional to avoid circular references. If we need to use this check to avoid this circular references then the correct response is to delay interpolation using quotes.

  if ty.TYPE_CHECKING:
      import bar

  def hello_world(foo: 'bar.Baz'):
      pass

When this is used, the type check is ignored by Python (it's just a string) but parsed by mypy, with the same caveats that 'bar' must be defined and the contents of 'bar' will only be checked if it's in the list of validated modules.

Now, to bring this back to 'nova.objects'. The quotes aren't to delay interpolation for mypy - they're to *prevent* it for Python. Because it attempts to evaluate the code, we *must* ensure 'nova.objects.register_all()' has been called before the module with the type hints is imported. If you don't, Python will fail with "module 'nova.objects' has no attribute 'Foo'" as soon as it tries to parse the module.  You can prove this from the REPL.

  (py36) $ python
  >>> from nova import objects
  >>> def test(instance: objects.Instance):
  ...     pass
  ...
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  AttributeError: module 'nova.objects' has no attribute 'Instance'
  >>> objects.register_all()
  >>> def test(instance: objects.Instance):
  ...     pass
  ...
  >>>

We can't guarantee that to be case so always surrounding anything from 'nova.objects' in quotes seems to be the correct thing to do. In addition, we will need to use quotes anytime we need to handle single quotes.
It doesn't fail if you do 'tox -e mypy'? Hmm, that's odd

swift/templates/bin/_build-rings.sh.tpl.message:
I do not think this will work right if you want to support day two operations - and you would have to if anyone wanted to use this in production. 

You need to be fetching the existing rings from Kubernetes and then adding *net new* disks.  This is the only way the ring will be able to rebalance data onto them.  Otherwise, you are creating rings from scratch each time with no reference to the old rings.  This works fine *until* the devices or nodes change.
It is usually useful to have weight be relative to the size of the disk, so that you can go from 100G disks to adding new nodes with 1T disks and the weight will be appropriately adjusted.

Is there value in any kind of historical representation of the ring so if you really needed to you could go back? In a production cluster, you would have the option (even if manually) to switch back to an older working ring as data loss is unacceptable.

This is needed to run keystone-api.sh as root user otherwise that command fails. I believe in SUSE most of non-general user command requires explicit sudo privilege. 

I recall seeing that in ubuntu, specific users are setup by 
"source /etc/apache2/envvars" . I don't see something similar on suse side.

Same gist as previous file's comment: Can we be more flexible here?

If we want OSH to be distro independent, we shouldn't add a value "image_distro". Instead we should probably split the templates into what semantically means something (that's what I meant in the previous file by 'if things should be ideally separated'), and have different values that can be injected by the deployers.

For example, I can definitely imagine a variable that can be modified per distro for the mountPath, and whose content will also be overriden per distro. At the end we would have files like a 'ubuntu xenial override', or a 'opensuse leap 15 override', each of them providing path to the right locations, and whose default content would be safe defaults for the distribution.

How do you feel about that?

As you correctly identified, this is distro specific mount path logic. Every distro will have some configuration files which are placed in different path and refer different content. And then there will be files which are additional or not applicable in specific distro. 

So requirement is to have ability to execute distro specific logic when defining k8s artifacts, probably based on a certain flag or condition which identifies the distro.

So now choice is around how to define them ?
If I am understanding correctly, are you suggesting to define them at some central place? It may also mean that we are moving artifact structure/format in that common area as there will be additional or 'not applicable' configuration files specific to a distro and hence addition and/or removal of config paths.

Imho, defining here seems more maintainable and explicit as we know what distro specific paths are applicable for that k8s artifact in that helm release component.

Can you clarify and provide more details about alternative approach?
could you clarify in the commit message why this needs to happen (vs ubuntu behaviour,where everything is in a single file)

This is different as vhosts config file default location is different and then need to provide access to wsgi script directory location.

If interested in details, check following.

https://doc.opensuse.org/documentation/leap/reference/html/book.opensuse.reference/cha.apache2.html#sec.apache2.configuration.manually.vhost

https://doc.opensuse.org/documentation/leap/reference/html/book.opensuse.reference/cha.apache2.html#sec.apache2.configuration.manually.vhost.basic_configuration

I partially agree with this approach, but I wanted to ask, if opencontrail ml2 conf is completely replacing the standard ml2 config file? 
I'm asking because in other neutron SDN solution ONOS SONA, the original ml2 config file is not changed but extra ml2 config file for sona is added:

  exec neutron-server \
        --config-file /etc/neutron/neutron.conf \
        --config-file /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini
{{- if .Values.conf.plugins.ml2_conf_onos.enabled }} \
        --config-file /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf_onos.ini
{{- end }}

So I was wondering if we can do something similar to opencontrail:

  exec neutron-server \
        --config-file /etc/neutron/neutron.conf \
        --config-file /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini
{{- if .Values.conf.plugins.ml2_conf_onos.enabled }} \
        --config-file /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf_onos.ini
{{- end }}
{{- if .Values.conf.plugins.ml2_conf_opencontrail.enabled }} \
        --config-file /etc/neutron/plugins/opencontrail/ContrailPlugin.ini
{{- end }}

I'm only asking to be consistent how we extend neutron chart with SDNs.

OpenContrail doesn't rewuire standard ml2 conf. Moreover - ml2 conf shouldn't be present.

This is the plugin's approach. ML2 is a plugin that is replaced by OpenContrail.

bsp-files/centos.syslinux.cfg.message: Why would we add this if it is the default? And why only add it to the serial console? I'd prefer not to change this file.

> Why would we add this if it is the default?
Because I need to sed it to =1 in "build-img --auto=...".

> And why only add it to the serial console?
I'll add it to graphical to be consistent (build-img only uses serial though)

> I'd prefer not to change this file.
Care to elaborate? To be clear: I need to avoid changing lvm.conf, because otherwise booting the image on a (virtual) motherboard with a slightly different disk/bus layout makes the image non-bootable. This definitely happens when booting in VirtualBox; I expect it to also happen if you choose a different drive emulation driver in quemu -- that is, different from what the installer uses (e.g., SATA instead of VIRTIO). Also relying on a particular bus layout seems fragile to me (ie might be qemu version specific).

Maybe look at using update-iso to generate a modified ISO that can be used for installing to a qcow image.
https://opendev.org/starlingx/utilities/src/branch/master/utilities/platform-util/scripts/update-iso.sh

It will allow you to add the install_portable=1 parameter:
update-iso -i bootimage.iso -o updated.iso -p install_portable=1

It also allows you to set the default boot menu item, and a timeout. So you could generate an updated iso that automatically runs an AIO serial installation, for example.

For that matter, you can also use its ks-addon.cfg feature that allows you to add a custom %post to the end of the kickstart, if you needed to tweak anything. Maybe that would allow you to do what you're trying to do without modifying the main kickstart files at all?

I am curious if your deployment or use case requires only some processes (and if so which one) to be behind  proxy while others do not.  That may help in refining and improving the documentation - to my knowledge, in most corporate settings, everything are behind the same proxy so a global application of this should suffice.

The proxy is set to solve the problem of the network environment in some areas. As you said, the modification in vars.yaml can affect all files, but only the special process needs to configure the proxy. If the setting is global, many services will be unavailable.
wouldn't the proxy setting be picked up via the docker setting (see Line 92) and we don't need to do any change on L102?
Since the build process of kubeadm-aio happens in ansible playbook, the outside docker settings will not be affected here, so additional configuration is required here.

doc/source/specs/osh-required-alert-list.message: In general, I'd avoid sticking to MariaDB and assume that other database may be used. So instead of retrieving MariaDB logs, we can retrieve database exceptions from oslo.db (https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/128e5438b14e596fc01032cc3bd1210391e77e19/oslo_db/exception.py - DBError and its children)
I've been also thinking about alerts related to Nova services issues (like compute service is down) - but I don't have an appropriate log pattern right now.

Proposal: average API response time (especially for Nova, Neturon) within a specified period of time is higher than a threshold. Example nova-api-osapi log:

  2017-11-15 12:07:06.505 1 INFO nova.osapi_compute.wsgi.server [req-cce1f487-68c2-4011-b3e8-c80e7376123c abb32d12995248b696eebaf10cd0270f dbb3940c171a427198c6a3b6a8772c45 - default default] 100.200.1.7,10.244.1.0 "GET /v2/dbb3940c171a427198c6a3b6a8772c45/servers/detail?all_tenants=1&limit=100 HTTP/1.1" status: 200 len: 206 time: 0.0661469

A new section for RabbitMQ alerts would be nice. We could catch transport related errors basing on oslo.messaging exceptions: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/exceptions.py

What is the thing that is actually taking a long time? The reserve or the save? Assuming the former, can we put the save outside the try..except so as not to confuse the timeout for the reserve with the save?

Also, is there any reason not to make this a long RPC call which can tolerate it legitimately taking a while? What's the actual thing making this take so long and ist here some reason not to use the call mechanism that will actually wait?
As I've already said this isn't about compute timeouts but failures by the compute to reply leading to timeouts on the API side.
